note.title: Fundamental Theorem of Line Integrals
note.fname: Vector Calculus.Line Integrals and Exact Differentials.Fundamental Theorem of Line Integrals

testing-if-a-field-is-conservative.text: Testing if a field is conservative

pageProps.body:
Fundamental Theorem of Line Integrals

Basic concepts

Recall the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus as stating that, for a function f(x)f(x)f(x) and its derivative f′(x)f'(x)f′(x) which exists over an interval a<x<ba < x < ba<x<b, we have

∫abf′(x) dx=f(b)−f(a)\int_{a}^{b} f'(x)\ dx = f(b) - f(a)∫ab​f′(x) dx=f(b)−f(a)

which, in perhaps much more meaningful terms, speaks simply thus: the total change of a function f(b)−f(a)f(b)-f(a)f(b)−f(a) over the interval (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) is the sum of the infinitesimal changes of the function f′(x)f'(x)f′(x) over that interval.

The question is, can the same statement - that the big swirly is the sum of all the little swirlies - be generalized, and how?

With the Fundamental Theorem of Line Integrals, we confirm that:

  1. The big swirly is still the sum of the little swirlies,
  2. The big swirly equals the sum of the little swirlies along any interval, from circles to smiley faces to the contours of Marie Antoinette's severed head (wig not included) - not just the same-old boring straight line from aaa to bbb.
  3. The big swirly equals the sum of the little swirlies of any function in any number of variables, not just single-variable functions - that is, as long as the (partial) derivatives of the function exist.

The mathematical statement that encapsulates all the above is as follows.

Theorem. Fundamental Theorem of Line Integrals. For a smooth curve CCC parameterized by ψ(t)\psi(t)ψ(t) for a<t<ba < t < ba<t<b and a function in any number of variables f(x)f(\mathbf{x})f(x) whose gradient vector ∇f\nabla f∇f is continuous on CCC, we have

∫C∇f⋅ds=f(ψ(b))−f(ψ(a))\int_C \nabla f\cdot d\mathbf{s} = f(\psi(b)) - f(\psi(a))∫C​∇f⋅ds=f(ψ(b))−f(ψ(a))

where ∫C∇f⋅ds\int_C \nabla f \cdot d\mathbf{s}∫C​∇f⋅ds denotes the vector-valued line integral.

Despite integrating far more bells and whistles into its ensemble, this says exactly the same thing as the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus:

The total change of a function from the starting point to the endpoint of a curve (f(ψ(b))−f(ψ(a))f(\psi(b)) - f(\psi(a))f(ψ(b))−f(ψ(a))) is equal to the sum of the infinitesimal changes of that function along the direction of the curve (∇f⋅ds\nabla f \cdot d\mathbf{s}∇f⋅ds, where the dot product gives the magnitude in the direction of the curve).

The intuition behind this statement is as clear as any mathematical theorem can hope to be (which to some people is "very", and to others like me, is "not at all"):

  1. ∇f\nabla f∇f gives the multi-dimensional analogue to the "rate of change" of the function fff (that is, it is the vector which contains the rate of change in every direction, represented by the partial derivatives of fff)
  2. The dot product ∇f⋅ds\nabla f \cdot d\mathbf{s}∇f⋅ds gives the magnitude of the rate of change of fff, represented by ∇f\nabla f∇f, in the direction of the curve CCC.
  3. The sum of the infinitesimal rates of change along the curve CCC is the total change from the starting point to the end point of CCC.

But enough intuition - let's give a proof!

Proof.

Let fff be a vector field in Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn. Then

∫C∇f⋅ds=∫C∇f(ψ(t))⋅ψ′(t) dt=∫ab∑i=1nfxi(ψ(t))ψ′(t)i dt=∫ab∑i=1n∂f∂xi∂xi∂t dt\begin{aligned} \int_C \nabla f \cdot d\mathbf{s} \\ = \int_C \nabla f(\psi(t)) \cdot \psi'(t) \ dt \\ = \int_{a}^{b} \sum_{i=1}^n f_{x_i}(\psi(t))\psi'(t)_i\ dt \\ = \int_{a}^b \sum_{i=1}^n \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_i}\frac{\partial x_i}{\partial t} \ dt \end{aligned}∫C​∇f⋅ds=∫C​∇f(ψ(t))⋅ψ′(t) dt=∫ab​i=1∑n​fxi​​(ψ(t))ψ′(t)i​ dt=∫ab​i=1∑n​∂xi​∂f​∂t∂xi​​ dt​

as the parameterization of C=ψ(t)C = \psi(t)C=ψ(t) gives

ψ(t)=[x1x2⋮xn]\psi(t) = \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \\ \vdots \\ x_n \end{bmatrix}ψ(t)=⎣⎡​x1​x2​⋮xn​​⎦⎤​

along CCC, and thus

ψ′(t)=[dx1dtdx2dt⋮dxndt]\psi'(t) = \begin{bmatrix} \frac{dx_1}{dt} \\ \frac{dx_2}{dt} \\ \vdots \\ \frac{dx_n}{dt} \end{bmatrix}ψ′(t)=⎣⎡​dtdx1​​dtdx2​​⋮dtdxn​​​⎦⎤​

leading to the above. As

∑i=1n∂f∂xi∂xi∂t=∂f∂t\sum_{i=1}^n \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_i}\frac{\partial x_i}{\partial t} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial t}i=1∑n​∂xi​∂f​∂t∂xi​​=∂t∂f​

by the multivariate chain rule, we thus have

∫ab∑i=1n∂f∂xi∂xi∂t dt=∫ab∂f∂t dt=f(ψ(b))−f(ψ(a))\int_{a}^b \sum_{i=1}^n \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_i}\frac{\partial x_i}{\partial t} \ dt = \int_{a}^{b} \frac{\partial f}{\partial t}\ dt = f(\psi(b)) - f(\psi(a))∫ab​i=1∑n​∂xi​∂f​∂t∂xi​​ dt=∫ab​∂t∂f​ dt=f(ψ(b))−f(ψ(a))

by the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus. This proof is also valid for piecewise smooth curves via finite subdivision to smooth curves.

By the above, we define

Definition. What do you call the farm where Margaret Thatcher, Ronald Reagan, and Donald Trump are buried together? A gender-neutral public toilet A conservative field.

(Please clap.)

Wait, no, let's try again:

Definition. If the vector field F\mathbf{F}F can be written as the continuous gradient ∇f\nabla f∇f of some other function fff, then F\mathbf{F}F is a conservative field.

The precise reasoning behind this rather interesting turn of phrase will be revealed in due time.

Path independence

The crucial consequence of the Fundamental Theorem of Line Integrals is the genuinely astonishing result that for certain functions - in particular, functions that are conservative fields - the line integral from point AAA to point BBB does not depend on the path chosen between those two points:

As long as path AAA and path BBB are the same points, you could take any path - from a straight line to a circle to the labyrinthine tunnels across Shrek's vomit-colored earholes - and end up with the same result.

Such a property is called

Definition. Path independence. If for a vector field F\mathbf{F}F and any two piecewise-smooth curves C1C_1C1​ and C2C_2C2​ with the same start and end points, we have

∫C1F⋅ds=∫C2F⋅ds,\int_{C_1} \mathbf{F \cdot ds} = \int_{C_2} \mathbf{F \cdot ds},∫C1​​F⋅ds=∫C2​​F⋅ds,

call F\mathbf{F}F path independent over these start and end points.

As stated by the above, conservative fields are path independent over any start and end point; thus we have

Theorem. The vector field F\mathbf{F}F, continuous over a domain DDD, is path independent in DDD if and only if it is a conservative field in DDD; that is, there exists some function fff such that F=∇f\mathbf{F} = \nabla fF=∇f.

Proof.

By the Fundamental Theorem of Line Integrals, if F=∇f\mathbf{F} = \nabla fF=∇f, then for any set of two points a,b∈D\mathbf{a, b}\in Da,b∈D and any two different piecewise-smooth curves C1,C2C_1, C_2C1​,C2​ connecting the two points, we have

∫C1F⋅ds=∫C1∇f⋅ds=F(a)−F(b)=∫C2F⋅ds,\int_{C_1}\mathbf{F}\cdot \mathbf{ds} = \int_{C_1}\nabla f \cdot \mathbf{ds} = \mathbf{F(a)-F(b)} = \int_{C_2}\mathbf{F\cdot ds},∫C1​​F⋅ds=∫C1​​∇f⋅ds=F(a)−F(b)=∫C2​​F⋅ds,

and thus a conservative field F\mathbf{F}F is path independent in DDD. Conversely, if for any vector field F\mathbf{F}F we have

∫C1F⋅ds=∫C2F⋅ds\int_{C_1}\mathbf{F}\cdot \mathbf{ds} = \int_{C_2}\mathbf{F\cdot ds}∫C1​​F⋅ds=∫C2​​F⋅ds

for any two piecewise-smooth curves C1C_1C1​ and C2C_2C2​ joining the same two points in DDD, suppose that

ϕ(y)=∫x→yF⋅ds\phi(\mathbf{y}) = \int_{\mathbf{x\to y}}\mathbf{F \cdot ds}ϕ(y)=∫x→y​F⋅ds

where x\mathbf{x}x is some fixed point and y\mathbf{y}y is a variable point in DDD. Our goal is to show that ∇ϕ=F\nabla \phi = \mathbf{F}∇ϕ=F and thus that F\mathbf{F}F is path independent by definition; taking the partial derivative with respect to variables x1,x2,...,xnx_1, x_2, ..., x_nx1​,x2​,...,xn​ of F\mathbf{F}F yields

∂ϕ∂xi=lim⁡ϵ→0ϕ(y+ϵi)−ϕ(y)ϵi\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial \phi}{\partial x_i} = \lim_{\epsilon \to \mathbf{0}}\frac{\phi(\mathbf{y} + \epsilon_i) - \phi(\mathbf{y})}{\epsilon_i} \\ \end{aligned}∂xi​∂ϕ​=ϵ→0lim​ϵi​ϕ(y+ϵi​)−ϕ(y)​​

where ϵi\epsilon_iϵi​ is the iiith component of a vector ϵ→0\epsilon \to \mathbf{0}ϵ→0, and thus

∂ϕ∂xi=lim⁡ϵ→01ϵi(∫x→(y+ϵi)F⋅ds−∫x→yF⋅ds)\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial \phi}{\partial x_i} = \lim_{\epsilon \to \mathbf{0}}\frac{1}{\epsilon_i}(\int_{\mathbf{x \to (y +\epsilon_i)}}\mathbf{F \cdot ds} - \int_{\mathbf{x \to y}}\mathbf{F\cdot ds}) \\ \end{aligned}∂xi​∂ϕ​=ϵ→0lim​ϵi​1​(∫x→(y+ϵi​)​F⋅ds−∫x→y​F⋅ds)​

and as the former line integral encompasses the same path as the latter line integral excepting the infinitesimal line from y\mathbf{y}y to y+ϵi\mathbf{y+\epsilon_i}y+ϵi​, we have

∂ϕ∂xi=lim⁡ϵ→01ϵi∫y→y+ϵiF⋅ds\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial \phi}{\partial x_i} = \lim_{\epsilon \to \mathbf{0}}\frac{1}{\epsilon_i}\int_{\mathbf{y \to y + \epsilon_i}}\mathbf{F \cdot ds} \\ \end{aligned}∂xi​∂ϕ​=ϵ→0lim​ϵi​1​∫y→y+ϵi​​F⋅ds​

and as ϵi\epsilon_iϵi​ is in the direction of xix_ixi​, ds\mathbf{ds}ds for the infinitesimal path from y→y+ϵi\mathbf{y \to y+\epsilon_i}y→y+ϵi​ is in the direction of the xix_ixi​-axis and F⋅ds\mathbf{F\cdot ds}F⋅ds is simply the iiith component of F\mathbf{F}F times the magnitude of ϵi\epsilon_iϵi​:

∂ϕ∂xi=lim⁡ϵ→01ϵiFiϵi=Fi\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial \phi}{\partial x_i} = \lim_{\epsilon \to \mathbf{0}}\frac{1}{\epsilon_i}\mathbf{F}_i \epsilon_i = \mathbf{F}_i \end{aligned}∂xi​∂ϕ​=ϵ→0lim​ϵi​1​Fi​ϵi​=Fi​​

as desired.

Closed paths

All of the above naturally leads us to a corresponding result that is just as consequential. First define

Definition. The piecewise-smooth curve CCC is a closed path in a domain DDD if its starting and ending points are the same point. Denote a line integral over a closed path CCC by the symbol

∮C\oint_{C}∮C​

with the funny little swirly thing in the middle, which looks sufficiently like a treble clef to remind me of how I maybe should've just gone to music college and run away from all this Greek black magic instead.

For conservative fields, closed-path line integrals aren't all that bad.

Theorem. F\mathbf{F}F is a conservative field over a domain DDD if and only if, for any closed path CCC within that domain, we have

∮CF⋅ds=0.\oint_C \mathbf{F\cdot ds} = 0.∮C​F⋅ds=0.

Finally, something that lets us take a bit of a breather!

Proof.

First suppose that F\mathbf{F}F is a conservative field equalling the gradient vector ∇f\nabla f∇f for some function fff. By the Fundamental Theorem of Line Integrals, we have

∫CF⋅ds=f(b)−f(a)\int_{C}\mathbf{F\cdot ds} = f(\mathbf{b}) - f(\mathbf{a})∫C​F⋅ds=f(b)−f(a)

where b\mathbf{b}b and a\mathbf{a}a are the ending and starting points of curve CCC respectively. If instead b=a\mathbf{b = a}b=a, meaning that the curve is a closed path, we simply have

∫CF⋅ds=f(b)−f(b)=0\int_{C}\mathbf{F\cdot ds} = f(\mathbf{b}) - f(\mathbf{b}) = 0∫C​F⋅ds=f(b)−f(b)=0

as desired.

Conversely, suppose that

∮CF⋅ds=0\oint_C \mathbf{F\cdot ds} = 0∮C​F⋅ds=0

for any closed path in DDD. Suppose that C1C_1C1​ and C2C_2C2​ are two distinct piecewise-smooth curves that join the same points a\mathbf{a}a and b\mathbf{b}b in DDD. Then the piecewise smooth curve, formed by joining C1C_1C1​ and −C2-C_2−C2​ (C2C_2C2​ with direction reversed), is a closed path as its starting point matches its ending point:

Denote this path CCC. By our assumption, we have

∮CF⋅ds=∫C1F⋅ds−∫C2F⋅ds=0\oint_C \mathbf{F\cdot ds} = \int_{C_1} \mathbf{F \cdot ds} - \int_{C_2} \mathbf{F\cdot ds} = 0∮C​F⋅ds=∫C1​​F⋅ds−∫C2​​F⋅ds=0

thus implying that

∫C1F⋅ds=∫C2F⋅ds\int_{C_1} \mathbf{F \cdot ds} = \int_{C_2} \mathbf{F \cdot ds}∫C1​​F⋅ds=∫C2​​F⋅ds

for any two curves C1C_1C1​ and C2C_2C2​ joining the same starting and ending points in DDD. It follows that F\mathbf{F}F is path independent in DDD, and, by the above theorem linking path independence to conservatism, that F\mathbf{F}F is a conservative field.

Putting the "conservative" in "conservative field"

Here's a fun one for all you physics enjoyers out there! (read: LITERALLY NO ONE, and if you happen to be one, then if we were ever friends, I hang my head in shame over my dreadfully poor judgment and hereby renounce our friendship. )

In Newtonian mechanics, an obscure but important fact is that the force acting upon a particle is related to the second-order derivative of its position - in saner, less deranged terms, its acceleration - by the following equation:

F=mx¨,\mathbf{F} = m\ddot{\mathbf{x}},F=mx¨,

where F\mathbf{F}F denotes force, mmm denotes the mass of the object, and x\mathbf{x}x denotes position. Essentially, the greater the mass, the greater the attraction; or, as Newton artfully stated upon gazing towards your mother, "I like 'em thicc".

We can interpret F\mathbf{F}F as a vector field - it maps every position x\mathbf{x}x along a smooth path taken by the object, denoted CCC, to a vector denoting the force experienced by the object. We already know that the line integral

∫CF⋅ds\int_{C} \mathbf{F \cdot ds}∫C​F⋅ds

represents the work done by the force F\mathbf{F}F along the path CCC; substituting Newton's Second Law (that's what this is called) into the above, and supposing that the curve CCC can be parameterized with respect to time as x=ψ(t)\mathbf{x} = \psi(t)x=ψ(t), suggests that

∫CF⋅ds=m∫Cx¨⋅ds=m∫ψ(a)ψ(b)x¨(t)⋅ψ′(t) dt=m∫ψ(a)ψ(b)x¨(t)⋅x˙(t) dt\begin{aligned} \int_C \mathbf{F\cdot ds} \\ = m\int_C \mathbf{\ddot{x} \cdot ds} \\ = m\int_{\psi(a)}^{\psi(b)} \mathbf{\ddot{x}(t)\cdot \psi'(t)}\ dt \\ = m\int_{\psi(a)}^{\psi(b)} \mathbf{\ddot{x}(t)\cdot \dot{x}(t)}\ dt \\ \end{aligned}∫C​F⋅ds=m∫C​x¨⋅ds=m∫ψ(a)ψ(b)​x¨(t)⋅ψ′(t) dt=m∫ψ(a)ψ(b)​x¨(t)⋅x˙(t) dt​

as the curve C=ψ(t)C = \psi(t)C=ψ(t) is the position vector x\mathbf{x}x along the curve and thus ψ(t)=x\psi(t) = \mathbf{x}ψ(t)=x, with a<t<ba < t < ba<t<b being the starting and ending points of the curve. Earlier results suggest that

ddt(x˙(t)⋅x˙(t))=2x¨(t)⋅x˙(t)\frac{d}{dt} (\mathbf{\dot{x}(t)\cdot \dot{x}(t)}) = 2\mathbf{\ddot{x}(t)\cdot \dot{x}(t)}dtd​(x˙(t)⋅x˙(t))=2x¨(t)⋅x˙(t)

for a vector x\mathbf{x}x due to the product rule; as such, we have

∫CF⋅ds=m2∫ψ(a)ψ(b)ddt(x˙(t)⋅x˙(t))=m2[∣x˙(ψ(b))∣2−∣x˙(ψ(a))∣2]\int_C \mathbf{F\cdot ds} = \frac{m}{2}\int_{\psi(a)}^{\psi(b)}\frac{d}{dt}(\mathbf{\dot{x}(t)\cdot\dot{x}(t)}) = \frac{m}{2}[|\mathbf{\dot{x}}(\psi(b))|^2 - |\mathbf{\dot{x}}(\psi(a))|^2]∫C​F⋅ds=2m​∫ψ(a)ψ(b)​dtd​(x˙(t)⋅x˙(t))=2m​[∣x˙(ψ(b))∣2−∣x˙(ψ(a))∣2]

where ∣x∣|\mathbf{x}|∣x∣ denotes the norm. The astute among you will notice that, as x˙\dot{\mathbf{x}}x˙ denotes the first-order derivative of position (in less clinically-insane terms, velocity), the above equation is the change in kinetic energy from t=at=at=a to t=bt=bt=b! This leads to

Theorem. The work-energy principle. The total work done on a particle along a path CCC is equal to the change in kinetic energy of the particle along that path:

WD=K(b)−K(a)WD = K(b) - K(a)WD=K(b)−K(a)

where WDWDWD denotes work done and K(b)K(b)K(b) denotes kinetic energy at time bbb.

We can say even more. Suppose now that the force field F\mathbf{F}F is a conservative field; it equals −∇V-\nabla V−∇V for some potential field VVV, where the negative sign is by convention. We thus have

WD=K(b)−K(a)WD = K(b) - K(a)WD=K(b)−K(a)

regardless of the path CCC chosen, as long as the start and end points are the same - energy is conserved, as all the energy being inputted into the system by some force (the work done) is utilized to change the velocity of the particle, i.e. converted to kinetic energy. We also have, as a consequence of the above theorems on conservative fields, that a conservative force will do no work along a closed loop.

Theorem. Law of Conservation of Energy (deservedly capitalized). A conservative force-field F\mathbf{F}F upholds the property that its total work done on a particle on a trajectory from point AAA to point BBB equals to the change of the kinetic energy of the particle beetween the two points, no matter the trajectory taken between the two points.

This - the conservation of energy - lends conservative fields their name, so named because they conserve energy (and not, in fact, because they'll begin spewing twenty racial slurs per second, or perform suspiciously-angled Roman salutes, or suggest that they're incapable of doing positive work "because of woke" when integrated over a closed loop.)

Testing if a field is conservative

Ask them where they were during the years 1933-1945.

By definition, a conservative field F=∇ϕ\mathbf{F = \nabla \phi}F=∇ϕ satisfies

Fi=∂ϕ∂xi\mathbf{F}_i = \frac{\partial \phi}{\partial x_i}Fi​=∂xi​∂ϕ​

for all i=1,2,...,ni = 1, 2, ..., ni=1,2,...,n. Taking the partial derivative another time gives

∂∂xjFi=∂2ϕ∂xi∂xj=∂∂xiFj\frac{\partial}{\partial x_j}\mathbf{F_i} = \frac{\partial^2 \phi}{\partial x_i \partial x_j} = \frac{\partial}{\partial x_i}\mathbf{F_j}∂xj​∂​Fi​=∂xi​∂xj​∂2ϕ​=∂xi​∂​Fj​

by equality of mixed partial derivatives given the local continuity of the derivatives of ϕ\phiϕ, for any i,j=1,2,...,ni, j = 1, 2, ..., ni,j=1,2,...,n. As such, we have

Theorem. If for a vector field F:Rn→Rn\mathbf{F}: \mathbb{R^n \to R^n}F:Rn→Rn we have

∂∂xjFi=∂∂xiFj\frac{\partial}{\partial x_j}\mathbf{F_i} = \frac{\partial}{\partial x_i}\mathbf{F_j}∂xj​∂​Fi​=∂xi​∂​Fj​

for any i,j=1,2,...,ni, j = 1, 2, ..., ni,j=1,2,...,n, then F\mathbf{F}F is a conservative field (barring some annoying exceptions). In fact, this is not only a necessary but a sufficient condition; it is an "if and only if" statement, though this fact is not immediately evident at present.

Let's take a look at one particularly annoying exception.

Example. Is the vector field F=(−yx2+y2,xx2+y2)\mathbf{F} = (-\frac{y}{x^2+y^2}, \frac{x}{x^2+y^2})F=(−x2+y2y​,x2+y2x​) conservative?

Solution

Performing the aforementioned test gives

∂Fx∂y=−(x2+y2)−2y2(x2+y2)2=−(x2−y2)(x2+y2)2=y2−x2(x2+y2)2∂Fy∂x=(x2+y2)−2x2(x2+y2)2=y2−x2(x2+y2)2\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial F_x}{\partial y} &= -\frac{(x^2+y^2)-2y^2}{(x^2+y^2)^2} \\ &= -\frac{(x^2-y^2)}{(x^2+y^2)^2} \\ &= \frac{y^2 - x^2}{(x^2+y^2)^2} \\ \\ \frac{\partial F_y}{\partial x} &= \frac{(x^2+y^2)-2x^2}{(x^2+y^2)^2} \\ &= \frac{y^2 - x^2}{(x^2+y^2)^2} \end{aligned}∂y∂Fx​​∂x∂Fy​​​=−(x2+y2)2(x2+y2)−2y2​=−(x2+y2)2(x2−y2)​=(x2+y2)2y2−x2​=(x2+y2)2(x2+y2)−2x2​=(x2+y2)2y2−x2​​

which shows signs of ardent and true conservatism - it can be swiftly verified that F=∇tan⁡−1(yx)\mathbf{F} = \nabla \tan^{-1}(\frac{y}{x})F=∇tan−1(xy​). But watch as the veil of conservative ardor is ripped with utmost haste from the traitorous visage of F\mathbf{F}F to reveal - DIOS MIO, A LIBERAL!

The evidence? Consider, for instance, the line integral around the closed loop formed by the circle CCC represented by x2+y2=1x^2 + y^2 = 1x2+y2=1 with radius 111 about the origin. Parameterizing the circle as (x,y)=(cos⁡t,sin⁡t), 0<t<2π(x,y) = (\cos t, \sin t),\ 0 < t < 2\pi(x,y)=(cost,sint), 0<t<2π leads to

∮CF⋅ds=∮02π(−yx2+y2,xx2+y2)⋅ddt(cos⁡t,sin⁡t) dt=∫02π(−sin⁡t,cos⁡t)⋅(−sin⁡t,cos⁡t) dt=∫02πcos⁡2t+sin⁡2t dt=∫02π1 dt=[1]02π=2π\begin{aligned} \oint_{C} \mathbf{F\cdot ds} \\ = \oint_{0}^{2\pi} (-\frac{y}{x^2+y^2}, \frac{x}{x^2+y^2}) \cdot \frac {d}{dt}(\cos t, \sin t)\ dt \\ = \int_{0}^{2\pi} (-\sin t, \cos t)\cdot (-\sin t, \cos t)\ dt \\ = \int_0^{2\pi} \cos^2 t + \sin^2 t \ dt \\ = \int_0^{2\pi} 1\ dt \\ = [1]^{2\pi}_0 \\ = 2\pi \end{aligned}∮C​F⋅ds=∮02π​(−x2+y2y​,x2+y2x​)⋅dtd​(cost,sint) dt=∫02π​(−sint,cost)⋅(−sint,cost) dt=∫02π​cos2t+sin2t dt=∫02π​1 dt=[1]02π​=2π​

which is decidedly not zero, as the closed-loop integral of a well-behaved conservative field should be. But why? The catch lies at the point (0,0)(0,0)(0,0), where F\mathbf{F}F is not at all well-defined. This is an important caveat - the closed-loop integral of a conservative field is only zero if the field is well-defined for every point inside that closed loop!
